code: @Manual{,   title = {morestopwords: All Stop Words in One Place},   author = {Fabio Ashtar Telarico and Kohei Watanabe},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.2.0},   url = {https://fatelarico.github.io/morestopwords}, }

what: All Stop Words in One Place
title: All Stop Words in One Place
text: Author: Fabio Ashtar Telarico, University Ljubljana, FDV

title: All Stop Words in One Place
text: stopwords R package originally developed Kohei Watanabe Waseda Institute Advanced Study (check publications ) provides easy access stopwords 50 languages Stopwords ISO library. package updated since Dec 22, 2017 installable anymore GitHub. , reboot happened grant continuity project.

title: All Stop Words in One Place
All Stop Words in One Place
All Stop Words in One Place
text: code base changed since version 0.1.0 (last maintained Dr. Watanabe). Now, function stopwords::stopwords() supports two-letter ISO codes, also three-letter ones. Moreover, can identify languages ISO name (e.g., German, Deutsch; Swedish, Sverige, etc.).

title: All Stop Words in One Place
text: package stopwords also based Watanabe’s archived GitHub repository. Thus, similar morestopwords, . However, two packages differentiated design choices features: morestopwords got dependencies integrates package cld2. morestopwords can (cld2 installed) identify language one () string(s) automatically morestopwords can remove stop words one strings either conjuction language detection independently. morestopwords allow user choose list stop words use. Rather, tries provide comprehensive list intuitive way. morestopwords’s lists include stop words single list included stopwords.

what: Removes stop words for a string the language of which is known — del.stopwords
title: Removes stop words for a string the language of which is known — del.stopwords
text: Removes stop words string language known

title: Removes stop words for a string the language of which is known — del.stopwords
Removes stop words for a string the language of which is known — del.stopwords
text: str string delete stop words lang Either ISO 639-2/3 language name derive ISO 639-2 code. language names performs string matching.

title: Removes stop words for a string the language of which is known — del.stopwords
text: character vector corresponding string str without stopwords language lang

what: Returns ISO codes and names for all language or only those available in this package — languages
title: Returns ISO codes and names for all language or only those available in this package — languages
text: See relevant Wikipedia article details language codes.

title: Returns ISO codes and names for all language or only those available in this package — languages
Returns ISO codes and names for all language or only those available in this package — languages
text: available logical, whether return languages supported package.

title: Returns ISO codes and names for all language or only those available in this package — languages
text: data frame row languages (supported available TRUE) columns several ISO codes (639-2, 639-3, 639-1) name.

title: Returns ISO codes and names for all language or only those available in this package — languages
text: Note : ISO 639-1 code mainland Chinese changed zh-cn. list stop words variety Chinese spoken island Taiwan accessible using ISO 639-1 zh-tw name 'Chinese Taiwan'. Ancient Greek assigned artifact ISO 639-1 code (gr) none. ISO 639-2 639-3 codes grc.

title: Returns ISO codes and names for all language or only those available in this package — languages
code: # Return all languages in the ISO 639-2/3 standard languages() #>    ISO639-2 ISO639-3 ISO639-1             name #> 1       afr      afr       af        Afrikaans #> 2       ara      ara       ar           Arabic #> 3       hye      hye       hy         Armenian #> 4       eus      eus       eu           Basque #> 5       ben      ben       bn          Bengali #> 6       bre      bre what: Matches a string with the ISO 639-1 code available in this library — match.lang
title: Matches a string with the ISO 639-1 code available in this library — match.lang
text: See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_639-1 details language code.

title: Matches a string with the ISO 639-1 code available in this library — match.lang
Matches a string with the ISO 639-1 code available in this library — match.lang
text: lang Either ISO 639-2/3 language name derive ISO 639-2 code. language names performs string matching.

title: Matches a string with the ISO 639-1 code available in this library — match.lang
text: character vector containing two-letter ISO 639-1 code associated requested language.

what: Removes stop words for a string the language of which is known — remove.stopwords
title: Removes stop words for a string the language of which is known — remove.stopwords
text: Removes stop words string language known

title: Removes stop words for a string the language of which is known — remove.stopwords
Removes stop words for a string the language of which is known — remove.stopwords
text: str string vector strings delete stop words lang Either: 'auto' case cld2 used perform language detection; string (vector strings, depending str) representing ISO 639-2/3 language name derive ISO 639-2 code (language names, string matching performed) fallback Fallback language case cld2 fails detect language manually-specified string match supported language. Default 'English'.

title: Removes stop words for a string the language of which is known — remove.stopwords
text: strings (vector, depending str) corresponding string/s str without stop words language/s lang.

title: Removes stop words for a string the language of which is known — remove.stopwords
code: # Multiple strings in different languages remove.stopwords(str = c(Gibberish = 'dadas',                          Catalan = 'Adeu amic meu',                          Irish = 'Slan a chara',                          French = 'Je suis en Allemagne',                          German = 'Eich liebe Deutschland'),                  # Various ways of indicating the language                  lang = c(NA, 'cata', 'Iris', 'fr', 'deu'),                  # Yet another way                  fallback = 'english'                  ) #> [[1]] #> [1] "dadas" #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] "Adeu amic" #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] "Slan chara" #>  #> [[4]] #> [1] "Je Allemagne" #>  #> [[5]] #> [1] "Eich liebe Deutschland" #>

what: Collection of stopwords in multiple languages — stopwords
title: Collection of stopwords in multiple languages — stopwords
text: function returns stop words contained StopwordsISO repository.

title: Collection of stopwords in multiple languages — stopwords
Collection of stopwords in multiple languages — stopwords
text: lang Language retrieve stop word among supported StopwordISO. parameters supports: three-letter ISO 639-2/3 codes (e.g., 'eng'); two-letter ISO639-1 codes ('en'); names based ISO 639-2 codes ('English' 'english') unambiguous substrings ('engl', 'engli', etc.).

title: Collection of stopwords in multiple languages — stopwords
text: character vector containing stop words selected language listed StopwordISO repository.

title: Collection of stopwords in multiple languages — stopwords

title: Combined stop words for all languages — stopwordsISO
text: unique stopwords following databases: StopwordISO repository; python's Natural Language Toolkit (nltk); http://snowball.tartarus.org/algorithms/english/stop.txt stop-word list; R package quanteda; marimo repository; Perseus project; Aurélien Berra's list stop words Ancient Greek Latin (doi:10.5281/zenodo.3860343 ).

title: Combined stop words for all languages — stopwordsISO
text: Note: unicode characters escaped. un-escape , consider using:
code: library(AllStopwords)    if(!requireNamespace('stringi')){      install.packages('stringi')    }    data('stopwordsISO')    stopwords_unescaped <- lapply(stopwordsISO,                                  stringi::stri_unescape_unicode)
